official-title.#text:
To suspend the authority for the Western Hemisphere
		  Institute for Security Cooperation (the successor institution to the United
		  States Army School of the Americas) in the Department of Defense, and for other
		  purposes.

cosponsor.#text: Mr. Danny K. Davis of Illinois

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Latin America Military Training Review
			 Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text:
Suspension of
			 authority for Western Hemisphere Institute for Security Cooperation

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall suspend the operation
			 of the Western Hemisphere Institute for Security Cooperation until the
			 submission of the report under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Latin America Military Training Review Act/s:4/ss:e

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
to operate an
			 education and training facility under
, is suspended until the submission of the report under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Latin America Military Training Review Act/s:4/ss:e

text.#text: The authority of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
for Latin
			 American military personnel (as a successor to the United States Army School of
			 the Americas, the Western Hemisphere Institute for Security Cooperation, or
			 otherwise) until the submission of the report under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Latin America Military Training Review Act/s:4/ss:e

text.#text:
No training
			 or education facility may be established in the

header.#text:
Limitation on
			 establishment of new education and training facility

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to provide to military personnel of Latin American nations.

text.#text:
There
			 is established a joint congressional task force to conduct an assessment of the
			 kind of education and training that is appropriate for the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Speaker of the House of Representatives
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Speaker of the House of Representatives

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: minority leader of the House of Representatives
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: minority leader of the House of Representatives

text.#text:
The
			 task force shall be composed of eight Members of Congress, of whom two each
			 shall be designated by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: a report on the assessment conducted under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Latin America Military Training Review Act/s:3/ss:a

text.#text:
Not
			 later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the task force
			 shall submit to

a
			 critical assessment of courses, curriculum, and procedures appropriate for
			 education and training of military personnel of Latin American nations;
			 and

an evaluation of
			 the effect of such education and training on the performance of Latin American
			 military personnel in the areas of human rights and adherence to democratic
			 principles and the rule of law.

term.#tail:
includes a Delegate to, or Resident
			 Commissioner in,

text.#text:
In
			 this section, the term

header.#text:
Commission to
			 investigate human rights abuses at the United States Army School of the
			 Americas

text.#text:
There is established a commission to
			 investigate the activities of the United States Army School of the Americas and
			 its successor institution, the Western Hemisphere Institute for Security
			 Cooperation.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Speaker of the House of
			 Representatives
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Speaker of the House of Representatives

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: minority leader of the House of Representatives
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: minority leader of the House of Representatives

text.#text:
The commission shall be composed of eight
			 members, of whom two each shall be appointed by the

Members
			 of the commission shall be selected from among individuals with knowledge and
			 experience in foreign military training and international human rights who are
			 not officers or employees of the Federal Government.

The members of the commission shall be appointed not
			 later than 60 days after the date of the enactment of this Act.

Any vacancy of the commission shall not
			 affect the powers of the commission and shall be filled in the manner in which
			 the original appointment was made.

The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson of the
			 commission shall be elected by the members.

Members
			 of the commission shall serve without pay.

Each member of the
			 commission shall receive travel expenses, including per diem in lieu of
			 subsistence, in accordance with applicable provisions under

The commission may,
			 for the purpose of carrying out this section, hold hearings, sit and act at
			 times and places, take testimony, and receive evidence as the commission
			 considers appropriate.

The
			 commission may secure directly from any Federal department or agency such
			 information as the commission considers necessary to carry out the provisions
			 of this section. Upon request of the Chairperson of the commission, the head of
			 such department or agency shall furnish such information to the
			 commission.

Not
			 later than two years after the date on which all members of the commission have
			 been appointed, the commission shall complete an investigation into the
			 activities of the United States Army School of the Americas and its successor
			 institution, the Western Hemisphere Institute for Security Cooperation. The
			 investigation shall—

identify those
			 individuals responsible for drafting or approving manuals for use at either
			 such institution advocating tactics that violate international law or the laws
			 of the United States;

determine how such
			 manuals were used in training conducted by either such institution;

determine the
			 effect of such training; and

identify those
			 individuals responsible for teaching such tactics.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Latin America Military Training Review Act/s:4/ss:d

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
a
			 report containing the results of the investigation and recommendations for
			 actions in response to any violations of human rights to which training at the
			 United States Army School of the Americas or its successor institution, the
			 Western Hemisphere Institute for Security Cooperation, contributed.

text.#text:
Not
			 later than 30 days after the completion of the investigation under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Latin America Military Training Review Act/s:4/ss:e

text.#text:
The
			 commission shall terminate 30 days after the date of the submission of the
			 report under
